sense.def: a laboratory
dictionaryExamples: a science/computer lab
a lab technician
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are computer labs too. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a small piece of paper or other material which gives information about the thing it is attached to
dictionaryExamples: a warning label
Remember to put address labels on the suitcases.
The washing instructions should be on the label.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was the price label hanging from the skirt belt. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the name or symbol of a company that produces goods for sale, or the goods themselves or the company itself
dictionaryExamples: The group has signed  with a new record label.
A major/independent label will release their new album.
Her favorite designer label  is Armani.
Everything we produce goes out under our own label.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another style which I like is the clothes from big labels like Armani, Dolce and Gabanna and Hugo Boss, but they are very expensive. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a word or phrase that is used to describe the qualities of someone or something, usually in a way that is not fair
dictionaryExamples: He seems to be stuck with the label "troublemaker."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He pointed out that the label of "traveler" could only be given to those people who would be willing to spend a long period living in another country, enough time to understand the functioning of society and its rules and to be accepted as an "informed" citizen, or at least not to be regarded as a foreigner. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to fix a small piece of paper or other material to something which gives information about it
dictionaryExamples: She labeled all the packages and sent them out the same afternoon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you arrive at the railway station you have to by a ticket at one of the counters labeled "Fahrkarten." Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to describe the qualities of someone or something using a word or phrase
dictionaryExamples: He didn’t want to be labeled a complainer, so he didn’t raise any objection to the extra work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my concept, these are the real people who deserve to be labeled as celebrities and not the ones who, currently, carry these titles. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: work, especially the type of work that needs physical effort
dictionaryExamples: The car parts themselves are not expensive - it's the labor that costs so much.
manual labor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Several jobs did not even require the use of English, but were physical labor. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: workers, especially people who do practical work with their hands
dictionaryExamples: skilled/unskilled labor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By working on both draining specific roads and replacing the worn down asphalt simu[l]taneously, the city would be saving money on the labor. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: the number of people in a place who are available and willing to work
dictionaryExamples: The strong economy will create growth in the labor market.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The labor market in Russia is greatly influenced by the political situation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: all of the people available to work or actually employed in a particular area, industry, or company
dictionaryExamples: In this city, over 15 percent of the labor force are in jobs that require a bachelor's degree.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Young couples usually don't want to have more then one or two [children] and the labor force is declining. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the last stage of pregnancy when the woman gives birth to a baby
dictionaryExamples: She went into labor at twelve o’clock last night.

sense.def: an activity that is hard work but which you do because you enjoy it
dictionaryExamples: He prefers to paint the house himself - it's a labor of love.

sense.def: a room used for scientific work
dictionaryExamples: research laboratories
a computer laboratory
Laboratory tests suggest that the new drug may be used to treat cancer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was in my school, in a laboratory, when I lost it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a piece of equipment that is used to reach high places, consisting of short steps attached between two long sides
dictionaryExamples: She was up on a ladder, cleaning the window.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My grandfather fell down from the ladder yesterday while he [was] fixing the broken light bulbs. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: a series of increasingly important jobs or stages in a particular type of work or process
dictionaryExamples: a first step on the employment ladder

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Far too often it is not "the key" but "the missing link," preventing us from taking the next step on the career ladder. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a polite or old fashioned way of referring to or talking to a woman
dictionaryExamples: There's a young lady here to see you.
Ladies and gentlemen, may I have your attention.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A very nice lady offer[ed] me a ride home but I refuse[d]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay

sense.def: very relaxed and not seeming worried about anything, or causing people to feel this way
dictionaryExamples: a laid-back style of teaching
He's very laid-back.
The place had a laid-back atmosphere.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was very nice to be with laid-back people, not only because it led me to forget about unnecessary worries, but also it made me think about myself more thoroughly than before. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: a large area of water which has land all around it
dictionaryExamples: We used to go boating on that lake.
Lake Superior
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to visit the lake and swim in it. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a young sheep, or the flesh of a young sheep eaten as meat
dictionaryExamples: We were staying on a farm where there were newborn lambs.
roast lamb
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [O]n the farms, that were [along] the way, we could see lambs, ducks, cows, horses, dogs, chickens, cats and pigs. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a piece of equipment that produces light
dictionaryExamples: a table/bedside lamp
an oil lamp
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it is next to the lamp. Key English Test; A2; Burmese

sense.def: an area of ground, especially when used for a particular purpose such as farming or building
dictionaryExamples: This land here is good for growing potatoes.
We want to buy a plot of land to build a house.
They just bought 150 acres of land in Idaho.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One man talked about how people can use their land properly, how they [should] take care of their poultry farm or dairy farm, [and] how they can take care of their trees and crops. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Polish

sense.def: the surface of the earth that is not sea
dictionaryExamples: It is cheaper to drill for oil on land than at sea.
The treaty led to a dramatic reduction in the number of land-based missiles.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, the car is the fastest way of transportation by land [that] we have. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a country
dictionaryExamples: Ireland was my grandmother’s native land.
a land of ice and snow
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People across the globe like to travel, explore and experience a different land. International English Language Testing System; C2; English

sense.def: to arrive at a place in a plane or a boat, or to make a plane or a boat reach the land
dictionaryExamples: We should land in Madrid at 7:00 a.m.
The pilot said we would land in about 20 minutes.
We’d been sailing for three weeks by the time we landed at Miami.
We landed at Port Said in the early evening.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When we landed, my suitcase was not there. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: If an object or person lands somewhere, they fall to the ground there.
dictionaryExamples: The ball landed in the neighbor's garden.
She landed flat on her back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then, when your booking form landed on my door mat, I decided to take matters into my own hands and to pay a visit to this conference. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: to get or achieve something, usually something good
dictionaryExamples: He's just landed a new job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To return to our first point, people do not usually land a job in their field of study or childhood dream. International English Language Testing System; C2; Greek

sense.def: an arrival on the ground of an aircraft or boat
dictionaryExamples: an emergency landing
The flight was great and we had a smooth landing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The company said our landing would depend on the weather forecast. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a woman who you rent an apartment, house, room or land from
dictionaryExamples: Heather's  landlady lowered her rent when she said she might move out.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: May[be] I should tell my landlady about that. 
 Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: a man who you rent an apartment, house, room or land from
dictionaryExamples: I asked the landlord to fix the window.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I came downstairs [and] saw my landlord, [who] seemed very angry. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a place or building that you can easily recognize, especially one that helps you to know where you are
dictionaryExamples: a familiar landmark
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is situated on a rocky outcrop overlooking the river and is a landmark visible from many miles. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a building or other structure that is considered especially important
dictionaryExamples: a landmark skyscraper
The tower has been designated a national historic landmark.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What they enjoyed most was the bus tour of London, on Tuesday, as it was a chance for them to see all the famous landmarks without walking. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: an event which is famous or important in the history of something
dictionaryExamples: The invention of the silicon chip is a landmark in the history of technology.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This film will never be "Titanic" successful, or "Casablanca" successful, or "Matrix" successful, but it [will] always be a [...] landmark in the history of action and martial arts films, forever redefining its genre. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the appearance of an area of land, especially in the countryside
dictionaryExamples: a rural landscape
The castle dominates the landscape for miles around.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The landscape was beautiful with a lake, a lot of animals, birds, [and] many flowers. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: part of a road or track that is separated from the other parts, usually by a painted line
dictionaryExamples: the left/right/middle lane
the fast/express/slow lane
a bike lane
They're widening the highway to three lanes in each direction.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, most buses drive [i]n an extra lane. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a narrow road in the countryside or in a town
dictionaryExamples: He drives too fast along those narrow, country lanes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think the best place to buy all this junk food is from my aunty's sweet shop, just 2 miles down your lane. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: doing or getting the things that lead to rapid success and advancement
dictionaryExamples: Their  hard work and successful software put them in the fast lane.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, should you ask why people are not happier than before, the answer is that nowadays they spend more hours on work than before because modern life is mostly a life in the fast lane. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a type of communication used by the people of a particular country or by a particular group of people
dictionaryExamples: How many languages do you speak?
the English language
American Sign Language
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm learning a new language. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: communication between people, usually using words
dictionaryExamples: She has done research into how children acquire language.
Her language skills are excellent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Language is very important [for] communicat[ion] between people. Preliminary English Test; B1; Lithuanian

sense.def: words of a particular type, especially the words used by people in a particular job
dictionaryExamples: legal language
the language of business
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: English has become the language of science, so it seems, even though some of the papers, studies and publications are hard to read and understand. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a system of instructions that is used to write computer programs
dictionaryExamples: I'm not familiar with that programming language.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Students must have knowledge of at least one programming language, preferably Visual C++. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Hungarian

sense.def: very rude and offensive words
dictionaryExamples: There was a lot of foul language in the movie.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is the responsibility of the parents not to fight or use any foul language in front of the kids, as they may learn and use it in front of others. International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi

sense.def: words that some people might consider to be offensive
dictionaryExamples: The movie contains strong language.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But what I do see is local kids standing [on] the corner, chat[t]ing, smoking and using strong language. Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; Slovak

sense.def: a computer that is small enough to be carried around and used where you are sitting
dictionaryExamples: A laptop would be really useful for when I'm working on the train.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think the laptop is in your bedroom. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: big in size or amount
dictionaryExamples: a large house
the world's largest computer manufacturer
I’d like a large soda.
This apartment is much larger than our last one.
We didn't expect such a large number of people to attend the concert.
We've made good progress, but there's still a large amount of work to be done.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's the new Nokia 380S. I like its large screen and its video camera. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: in general
dictionaryExamples: By and large, people have welcomed the changes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would say that, by and large, tourism in the world today is more beneficial than harmful. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: people or things in general
dictionaryExamples: This group is not representative of the population at large.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Television - sometimes also described as the "idiot box" - has been accused of turning a whole generation into "couch potatoes" and blamed for every malady affecting the society at large. International English Language Testing System; C2; Gujarati

sense.def: If something looms large, it becomes very important and often causes worry.
dictionaryExamples: The issue of pay will loom large at this year's conference.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was, she dreaded to admit, a sense of regret. She shock her head as if doing so shooed the feeling away.  On the contrary, however, it was looming large while she was stamping along the busy street. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: almost completely
dictionaryExamples: a largely male company
Their complaints were largely ignored.
His early novels went largely unnoticed.
The damage caused by the flooding has been largely unreported in the press.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What I'm trying to say is that images, film-frames, videos and sound clips would be largely accepted by the young people because we're moving into a new high-technology age. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a machine that produces a strong beam of light that has medical and technical uses or a beam of light produced by a machine like this
dictionaryExamples: laser beam
laser surgery
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These appliances have been the key to medical achievements, such as laser-based surger[y] or different kinds of diagnosis and treatment. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: finally
dictionaryExamples: And lastly, I'd like to thank everyone who took part in the event.

sense.def: the latest possible opportunity for doing something

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were very disappointed to hear that the actor was replaced by [an]other at the last minute. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: done at the latest possible opportunity
dictionaryExamples: a last-minute cancellation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could come the following day to help you [with] the last-minute preparations if you want [me] to. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the name that you and other members of your family all have
dictionaryExamples: Her first name is Sarah but I don't know her last name.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Brown was his last name. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: happening or arriving after the planned, expected, usual or necessary time
dictionaryExamples: This train is always late.

Sorry I'm late. I was caught in traffic.
We always have a late breakfast on Sunday mornings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope I am not late. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: happening or being near the end of a period of time
dictionaryExamples: It was late at night.
I better get going - I had no idea it was so late!

It was built in the late nineteenth century.
I expect him home late this afternoon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like the time the class finish[es]. It's too late! Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: describes someone who has died, especially recently
dictionaryExamples: She gave her late husband's clothes to charity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It took me a while to find a person whom I regard as successful, the outcome is a friend of my late father. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: used after a time or date to say that something could happen before but not after that time
dictionaryExamples: She said to be there by 8 o'clock at the latest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as employment is concerned, as people take their pensions at the age of 65 at the latest, new staff cannot be recruited. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: after the planned, expected, usual or necessary time
dictionaryExamples: Kathryn's just phoned to say she's working late this evening.
The snow came late this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The party finished late. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: near the end of a period of time
dictionaryExamples: We talked late into the night.
As late  as the 1980s they were still using horses on this farm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, he usually starts working at eight in the morning and he keeps on writing and phoning till late in the evening. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: recently
dictionaryExamples: Lately, I've been walking to work.
I haven't been feeling so well lately.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sorry I couldn't write back to you before but I've been very busy lately. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: being the newest or most recent or modern
dictionaryExamples: Have you seen her latest movie?
the latest fashions
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like it very much, because it is the latest model and nobody at our school ha[s] it. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: near or toward the end of something
dictionaryExamples: Construction on the new library should begin in the latter part of next year.
In the latter stages of the race he began to tire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I agree with the latter opinion. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the second of two people, things or groups previously mentioned
dictionaryExamples: They only seats available were off to the side or up in the balcony -  I chose the latter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The former is a Chinese restaurant and the latter an Indian. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to smile while making sounds with your voice that show you are happy or think something is funny
dictionaryExamples: They laughed at her jokes.
I couldn't stop laughing.
I said he'd have to give a talk and he laughed nervously.
She's so funny - she really makes me laugh.
It's very rare that a book is so good you actually laugh out loud.
It was so funny, I burst out laughing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We laughed all the time. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: If a subject is no laughing matter, it is serious and not something that people should joke about.
dictionaryExamples: Being late for a job interview is no laughing matter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anna and Tom knew this was no laughing matter. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

dictionaryExamples: I can't go into work looking like this - everyone will laugh at me.
If you say that, people will just laugh at you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All my friends laughed at me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: the act or sound of laughing
dictionaryExamples: a loud/nervous laugh
I was embarrassed at the time, but I had a good laugh about it later.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a beautiful beach there where you can swim, play football and enjoy a good laugh with your friends. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swedish

sense.def: the act or sound of laughing
dictionaryExamples: She roared with laughter.
As we got nearer the hall we could hear laughter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People need music, joy and laughter. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to start an important plan or activity, or begin something
dictionaryExamples: The program was launched a year ago.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Phil, I was very proud last Monday when you asked me to help you to launch this association.  First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: If a company launches a product or service, it makes it available for the first time.
dictionaryExamples: We’re planning to launch a new Internet company next month.
The airline will launch its new transatlantic service next month.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The firm was launching a new product and Peter was the manager in charge [of] making this product the most desirable thing to buy. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to send a spacecraft or rocket into the sky, or a ship into the water
dictionaryExamples: On the last shuttle mission, the crew launched a communications satellite.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Could our grandparents or grandparents' parents imagine that one day, we would be able to launch rockets, to have satellites in the sky? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the start of a  new plan or activity
dictionaryExamples: The launch of their new campaign began today with a press conference.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As for the natural resources, it is not very effective as nothing has changed since the launch of the campaign. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the introduction of a new product or service, or an event to celebrate this
dictionaryExamples: Frank went to the launch for the company's new LCD TVs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For instance, one of those major companies is about to launch the microwave version of one of our region's most famous meals. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: the launching of a spacecraft, ship, or weapon
dictionaryExamples: The launch of the space shuttle was delayed for 24 hours because of bad weather.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If not every member supports every other member, if open handling of errors isn't done at all stages of the project, if not every member commits to the common target, then millions of euros and many years of work will be destroyed within a few seconds during the launch of the satellite. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: clothes, sheets, etc. that need to be washed
dictionaryExamples: to do the laundry
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Does the camp have laundry facilities? First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: showing that a lot of money has been spent
dictionaryExamples: a lavish meal/party
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Wilbur arrived later, too late for the compulsory martini but still on time for the lavish meal of 7 courses. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the subject or job of understanding and dealing with the official laws of a country
dictionaryExamples: to study/practice law
a law school/firm
civil/criminal/international law
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her name is Martina, she is twenty-one years old and she studies law in Bologna. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: an official rule made by a government
dictionaryExamples: state/federal law
labor/immigration laws
We have a law in this state that drivers must wear seatbelts.
Many states have passed laws against using a cell phone while driving.
The law is intended to protect wildlife.
Motor vehicle insurance is  required by law.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a special law in Sweden which allows everyone to wander along any private estate unless one causes any harm. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: the system of official rules in a country
dictionaryExamples: Playing loud music late at night is against the law.

You can't take that course of action and remain within the law.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a result, the law is being constantly broken. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: If you have to do something by law, it is illegal not to do it.
dictionaryExamples: They have to provide a contract by law.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They consist in preparing e-mails or letters, all formal, giving explanations to clients about their fiscal situation in Brazil, preparing and calculating tax returns, providing to [the] IRS our clients asset positions, which is required by law and also, having meetings with clients - this is the most important and exciting part of our work. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a statement or relationship that is always true in science, mathematics, etc.
dictionaryExamples: the laws of physics
the law of averages/gravity
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everything seamed less real or less personal when she thought of the universe as an ent[i]ty and of people as cells or even atoms circling freneti[cal]ly around an unseen nucle[u]s bound by laws of physics that could not be broken or avoided. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

blocks.phrase: take the law into your own hands

sense.def: to do something illegal in order to punish someone because you know that the law will not punish that person
dictionaryExamples: The police did nothing about the thefts, so they took the law into their own hands.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, locals are scared to death, leading to their taking the law into their own hands. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the obeying of laws in society
dictionaryExamples: a breakdown in law and order
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The breakdown in law and order, lack of basic amenities to support life, absence of a fair and enabling enviro[n]ment for citizens to thrive, to mention but a few, are some among many factors [that] constitute the cogent reason why most Nigerians choose to travel out of their own country. International English Language Testing System; C2; Efik

sense.def: an area of grass that is cut to keep it short
dictionaryExamples: Will you mow the lawn this weekend?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please find enclosed a map of Brighton. Concerning the house, I ask you to mow the lawn regularly and to water the flowers and the green plants every day. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a problem taken to a court of law, by an ordinary person or an organization rather than the police, for a legal decision
dictionaryExamples: The lawsuit is aimed at protecting this species of  salamander.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unless such a plan is presented within a month, we will put high compensation claims in a lawsuit. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court
dictionaryExamples: I want to see my lawyer before I say anything.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that she thank[ed] me and she told me that she is a lawyer. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: an amount of a substance covering a surface, or one of several amounts of substance, each on top of the other
dictionaryExamples: the ozone layer
A thick layer of dust covered everything.
There was a thin layer of oil on the surface of the water.
We stripped several layers of paint off the door.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think clothes will have many gadgets on them like a small oxygen mask [or] a hat designed to protect people from the strong rays of the sun at midday because the ozone layer will be destroyed in a hundred years' [time]. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the way that something is arranged
dictionaryExamples: Each article in the journal has its own typeface and layout.
Do you like the layout of the kitchen?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Enhancements expanded to include building layout and structure. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: being lazy
dictionaryExamples: The only thing stopping me from getting to the gym is laziness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sorry I haven't dropped you a line before now - no excuses really, just laziness. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: A person who is lazy does not like working or using any effort.
dictionaryExamples: These kids are just too lazy to walk to school!

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you like drawing and if you aren't a lazy boy, attend the new art class! Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: slow and gentle or relaxed
dictionaryExamples: a lazy breeze

a lazy morning/weekend
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Newly arrived with all of my family on the French coast, we were getting set for a long lazy day on the beach. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to show someone where to go, usually by taking them to a place or by going in front of them
dictionaryExamples: I don't know the way, so you'd better lead.
She led them down the hall.
The waiter led us to our table.
Our guide led us through the mountains.
She took the child by the hand and led him upstairs to bed.
He led the horse out of the stable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And you can go to the nearest village, where you can [take a] mountain walk led by experienced guides. Preliminary English Test; B1; Hungarian

sense.def: If something, for example a path or road, leads somewhere, it goes in that direction.
dictionaryExamples: That path leads to the beach.
A flight of narrow stairs leads to the kitchen.
There's a road that leads toward the reservoir.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I discovered a small path which led to an old castle we had never seen before. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be winning a game or a competition
dictionaryExamples: Ngomo led by less than two seconds.
With only three minutes remaining, New Orleans led (Dallas), 24 to 21.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Marseille led 1-0 versus Milan AC in the match which qualified the winner for the semi-finals. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to be in control of a group, country, or situation
dictionaryExamples: I think we've chosen the right person to lead the expedition.
I've asked George to lead the discussion.
Her sister is leading an effort to change this law.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also led a group of people cleaning the wood just outside the city. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to live in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: She retired to Florida and still leads a busy life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Owing to the great speed of technological development, people need to lead a faster life [than before]. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to be better than anyone else
dictionaryExamples: I still believe that we lead the world in acting talent.

sense.def: to cause someone to do or think something
dictionaryExamples: What led you to think that?
The brochure led me to believe that the price included home delivery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The girl's disap[p]earance leads him to think she was taken away. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to cause you to think that something is probably true
dictionaryExamples: So you thought I was leaving, did you?  What led you to that conclusion?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These results lead us to the conclusion that only people with "minds tough enough" will survive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be caused or influenced by something
dictionaryExamples: Her actions were led by greed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main reason that I believe so is that they do not seem to possess any tendency to fall in love blindly and let themselves be led by instinct. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to cause something to happen or exist
dictionaryExamples: Reducing speed limits led to fewer fatal highway accidents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People who work very hard are often tired, which could influence their relationship with others. It might lead to unnecessary arguments and spoil the pleasant atmosphere among them for some time. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to happen before an event
dictionaryExamples: The pilot had no recollection of the events leading up to the crash.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We want to know what happened to those civilizations, what were their beliefs, [...] what were their dreams and predictions [for] the future, what events and actions have led up to the present? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a winning position during a race or other situation where people are competing, or  a position ahead of other people
dictionaryExamples: For the first time in the race Harrison is in the lead.
With a final burst of speed he moved into the lead.
She took the lead with ten meters to go in the race.
By the end of the day's play Davies had a lead of three points.
The whole family walked down to the beach, with Mom in the lead.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the last lap David took the lead with a professional overtake [of] Nilsons' Aston Martin. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the main person in a film or play
dictionaryExamples: She plays the lead in both films.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A child who leaves school feeling that he has succeeded in leaving his mark by holding the school record for high jump or getting the lead in the school production is a happy, confident child who is able to face the next chapter in his life knowing he can and will do well. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: The lead performer or lead part in a performance is the main performer or part.
dictionaryExamples: Who played the lead role?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was Dave Grohl, the lead singer of Foo Fighters! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a person in control of a group, country, or situation
dictionaryExamples: a business/community/political leader
a band leader
Meet your tour/group leader in front of the hotel.
The Russian leader wants to introduce further changes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I arrived there, the group leader introduced me to all the others, and they all were very friendly. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: someone or something that is first or most important
dictionaryExamples: Her company is a leader in the women’s clothing industry.
He's fallen two laps behind the leaders.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The work experience with SuNatCo must, [without] doubt, positively affect your future career, as our firm is a world leader in the sphere of communications. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: the set of characteristics that make a good leader
dictionaryExamples: What the company lacks is leadership.
He lacks leadership qualities/skills.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also have strong leadership skills and I can lead a team, if necessary. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: the job of being in control of a group, country, or situation
dictionaryExamples: The group flourished under her firm leadership.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Apart from his char[i]smatic leadership and his pioneering spirit, Eleftherios Venizelos was very close to people who were impoverished and deeply disappointed at that time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the people in control of a group, country, or situation
dictionaryExamples: There is growing discontent with the leadership.
The election for the leadership of the council will take place on Tuesday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His reappearance is when he wins the leadership of the Social Democratic Party and when a few months later he becomes Prime-Minster. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: very important or most important
dictionaryExamples: a leading expert on the country's ecology
the world's leading manufacturer of audio equipment
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Indeed hard work plays the leading role concerning both family welfare and [the] national economy. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a flat, green part of a plant that grows from a stem or branch
dictionaryExamples: a lettuce leaf
He was raking up leaves in his yard.
By early November it’s getting cold and the trees are starting to lose their leaves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the things that I like [about] goril[l]as is that they are strong and they eat leaves, and another thing is that they can move very fast through the trees. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to start to behave in a better way
dictionaryExamples: I turned over a new leaf and began getting to work on time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She promised to turn over a new leaf. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: on or more pieces of folded paper that gives information or advertises something
dictionaryExamples: They were handing out leaflets outside the supermarket about the school board election.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another idea is to place a table where students, staff and visitors can find some information about the school and their activities, some leaflets and brochures. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a group of teams that compete against each other in a sport
dictionaryExamples: the National League
the major/minor leagues
Will Boston win the league championship this year?
Our team has the worst record in the league.
Do you belong to a bowling league?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A TV company came to our school yesterday to make a film of our school's basket-ball team after winning first place at the state's league this year. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: If a liquid or gas leaks, it comes out of a hole or space by accident, and if a container leaks, it allows liquid or gas to come out when it should not.
dictionaryExamples: Water was leaking from the pipe.
Oil leaked out of the car.
The can is leaking.
The car leaked oil all over the drive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is always a possibilit[y] that this tent is leaking. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: If someone leaks secret information, they intentionally tell people about it.
dictionaryExamples: Details of the report had been leaked to the press.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "If these facts [were] leaked to the press, my career would be done for," he said. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a hole in something that a liquid or gas comes out of, or the liquid or gas that comes out
dictionaryExamples: There's water on the floor - we must have a leak.
If you think there's a gas leak, leave the house and call 911, the emergency number.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The theat[e]r restaurant was closed because there was a serious leak in a [pipe] and the kitchen was flooded. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: secret information that has intentionally been told to someone
dictionaryExamples: The Justice Department was investigating security leaks.
There have been several leaks to the press.

sense.def: to get knowledge or skill in a new subject or activity
dictionaryExamples: They learn Russian at school.
"Can you drive?" "I'm learning."
I learned a lot about computers since I started work here.
I'm learning to play the piano.
First you'll learn (how)to use this machine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes we start some game and after that we learn about some new things. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hindi

sense.def: to make yourself remember a piece of writing by reading it or repeating it many times
dictionaryExamples: I don't know how actors manage to learn all their lines.
We were told to learn Portia's speech by heart  for homework.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was a very famous and popular actor. He's very funny and he shows us very useful tricks to [help us] learn our roles. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to be told facts or information that you did not know
dictionaryExamples: Parents learned of the schedule change in a letter from the teacher.
I later learned (that) the message had never arrived.
I only learned about the accident later.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was pleased to learn that you are coming to Switzerland. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to start to understand that you must change the way you behave
dictionaryExamples: She'll have to learn that she can't have everything she wants.
She soon learned not to be late.
He's not afraid to learn from his mistakes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In team sports you can share your feelings with the others and you learn to become extroverted. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to learn something by experiencing a lot of problems or difficulty
dictionaryExamples: He doesn’t want to take my advice, so I guess he’ll have to learn the hard way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you don't know the past, you're liable to live through it again as instead of deriving the lessons from someone else's experiences, you'll have to learn them the hard way, by trial and error. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: someone who is getting knowledge or a new skill
dictionaryExamples: learners of English
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is very shy, so her Japanese didn't improve very rapidly, but she was a very industrious learner. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: the process of getting knowledge or a new skill
dictionaryExamples: language learning
This technique makes learning fun.
For the first month in her new job she was on a steep learning curve.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Th[ese] events are not only to entertain students, they are also a part of the learning process, as by communicating with each other, students learn the language. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: the skin of animals that is used to make things such as shoes and bags
dictionaryExamples: a leather jacket/belt/handbag
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And I g[o]t teddy bears, a cool leather jacket, and a pretty bag. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: to go away from a place or a situation, either permanently or for a temporary period
dictionaryExamples: The bus leaves in five minutes.
I'll be leaving at seven o'clock tomorrow morning.
He left the house by the back door.
She left the group of people she was with and came over to speak to us.
"Does Trevor still work there?" "No, he left last month."
She left school early.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I leave home at 7:30. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Farsi

sense.def: to put something in a place and forget to take it with you when you go
dictionaryExamples: Hey, you've left your keys on the table.
That's the second umbrella I've left on the train!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I have left my umbrella in the bathroom. Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: to put something in a place where it will stay
dictionaryExamples: You can leave your bags by the desk.
Why don't you leave the kids with me on Friday?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can you take my sunglasses and leave [them] in my house today? Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to put something somewhere for another person to have later
dictionaryExamples: I left some sandwiches for them to have later.
Can I leave a message for Sue?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will leave a short message for you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: to not use all of something
dictionaryExamples: They ate all the cake but left some cookies.
Are there any sandwiches left?
Please leave some coffee for me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Could you please help me to find out if there [are] any place[s] left and please let me know, when the course starts and when the course [will] finish. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish

sense.def: to end a relationship with a husband, wife, or partner
dictionaryExamples: He said he'd never leave.
She left him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jose, who is a bus driver, was very unhappy, because his girlfriend [had] left him. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to cause something to stay in a particular condition
dictionaryExamples: Leave that chair where it is.
Leave the light on in the living room.
I have to go back - I think I left the iron on.
You can leave the window open.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And I heard my husband shouting: "Mag, do you always have to leave all the lights on?" First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to stop speaking to or annoying someone
dictionaryExamples: Leave me alone! I'm trying to work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I asked [him] to leave me alone and [un]plugged the phone. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: If you leave something or someone doing something, you allow them to continue doing it, or they continue doing it when you go away.
dictionaryExamples: I left the children watching television.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She also has the tendency to leave the children doing what they want, sometimes without realising the consequen[c]es. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: to produce a particular, often bad, situation
dictionaryExamples: Far from improving things, the new law has left many people worse off  than before.

The family were left  homeless.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was born on a ranch in Jalisco, the fourth of eight children, and when the youngest was only six months old, my grandfather died, leaving the family penniless. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to do something later that you could do immediately
dictionaryExamples: Don't leave your packing till the night before you go.
I'll leave these letters till Monday.
Don't leave it too late.
They left booking their holiday till/to the last minute.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I left it until the following day since I was too worn out to go on. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to arrange for someone to receive something after you die
dictionaryExamples: He left his nieces all his money./He left all his money to his nieces.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "I hate him", Jane thought, "and [I wonder] why on earth Uncle John left him all his money and the most beautiful estate in our country with this old manor house, in which all my ancestors were born." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

blocks.phrase: leave someone to their own devices

sense.def: to leave someone to do what they want to do
dictionaryExamples: With both parents out at work, the kids were often left to their own devices.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The moment teenagers leave school, they are left to their own devices. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to do everything that you can in order to achieve something or to find someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Both sides have vowed to leave no stone unturned in the search for peace.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She has left no stone unturned so as to reach her [goal], always asserting her assets and views with conviction. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

blocks.phrasalVerb: leave behind sb/sth or leave sb/sth behind

sense.def: to leave a place without taking someone or something with you
dictionaryExamples: We were in a hurry and I think I must have left my keys behind.
The flood victims were forced to leave behind family photos and mementos.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know you must be disappointed [at] having to move, leaving all your friends behind, but it's OK, I'm sure you'll make new ones. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

blocks.phrasalVerb: leave out sb/sth or leave sb/sth out

sense.def: to not include someone or something
dictionaryExamples: You can leave the butter out of this recipe if you're on a low-fat diet.

She doesn't know any of the other children and I think she feels left out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She felt so left out. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: time allowed away from work for illness or another special purpose
dictionaryExamples: maternity/sick leave
She's (gone) on leave.
I've asked if I can take a week's unpaid leave.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A week before Christmas, when I still hadn't heard from your shop, I phoned again, and was told that Mrs Smith was on leave, but could I repeat my problem, which I did. International English Language Testing System; C2; English

sense.def: a formal talk on a serious or specialist subject given to a group of people, especially students
dictionaryExamples: We went to a lecture on Italian art.
Who's giving the lecture this afternoon?
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: It was [a] very interesting lecture. 
 Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to give a formal talk to a group of people, especially students
dictionaryExamples: She’s lecturing on the geology of the region.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After having lectured for almost 10 years, he decided to resign and start writing full-time. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a long white and green vegetable that smells and tastes similar to an onion
dictionaryExamples: potato and leek soup
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had some roasted chicken pieces with some leek and broccoli and roasted potatoes and Jan had his favorite spaghetti with cream sauce. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: on or toward the side of your body that is to the west when you are facing north
dictionaryExamples: He injured his left eye.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tomorrow I must to go to the doctor because of my left leg, I can't walk any more. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: to the side of your body that is west when you are facing north
dictionaryExamples: Turn left at the light.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you go out of Kilburn station, you turn left and you go straight. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: the left side of your body, or the direction toward this side
dictionaryExamples: First I'll introduce the speaker sitting on my left.
Your seat is the third from the left.
It's to the left of the bookcase.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's on the left. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: political groups that support economic equality and believe government should provide social services
dictionaryExamples: The proposals were sharply criticized by the left.

sense.def: on or to the left of something
dictionaryExamples: There's a sign on the left-hand side.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the bus arrives at City Hall, you can jump out, and my house is [on the] left-hand side by City Hall. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Portuguese

sense.def: supporting economic equality and government-funded social services
dictionaryExamples: He is interested in left-wing politics.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Women's politics are usually followed by the left-wing parties in Austria. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: one of the parts of the body of a human or animal that is used for standing and walking
dictionaryExamples: My legs were tired after so much walking.
He broke his leg skiing.
The horse broke its front leg in the fall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He has broken his leg and I must look after him. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish

sense.def: a situation that was caused by something from an earlier time
dictionaryExamples: The war has left a legacy of hatred.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many of his novels deal with the social and political problems facing his country, including the difficulty of the post-colonial legacy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: money or property that you receive from someone after they die
dictionaryExamples: An elderly cousin had left her a small legacy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Falcon Crest was the name of an estate set in the prosperous vin[e]yards of the California Valley, and the plot dealt with the intrigues woven by a widow, Angela Chaming, to [solid]ify her control over the region, and to leave her beloved grandson a powerful solid legacy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: relating to the law
dictionaryExamples: the legal profession
legal counsel
a legal requirement
your legal rights
legal action
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sure you will accept my request; if not I intend to take legal action against your company. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: allowed by the law
dictionaryExamples: Is it legal to cross the border and buy prescription drugs in another country?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can anybody say how any enterprise should or must work? Is it legal? First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: as stated or allowed by the law
dictionaryExamples: The contract is legally binding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He already had a driving licen[s]e, so by that time he could legally drive his own Ferrari. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: an old story or set of stories from ancient times
dictionaryExamples: The dance was based on several Hindu legends.
She is writing a thesis on Irish legend and mythology.
Legend has it  that he always wore his boots in bed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know I'm fond of medieval tales and legends, so while we're in Scotland, let's visit a haunted castle! First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a famous person
dictionaryExamples: a living legend
Jazz legend, Ella Fitzgerald, once sang in this hall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They didn't even knew it of course that they would become legends for the generations to come and this fact makes this hypothetical travel such a fascinating experience only on the thought of it! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: famous for being excellent
dictionaryExamples: the legendary guitarist Jimi Hendrix
He became editor of the legendary Irish journal, "The Bell."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I went back to the beginning of [the] 70s, then I would probably have [had] a chance to work with Bill Gates and his legendary crew. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: from an ancient legend
dictionaryExamples: a legendary Greek hero
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The last article concerned Hercules, the legendary hero. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a law or a set of laws
dictionaryExamples: The government has promised to introduce legislation to limit fuel emissions from cars.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And while governments have taken measures to reduce emission of fuels into the atmosphere and prevent toxic waste from being discharged into the oceans, the existing legislation is not rigorously enforced. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: reasonable and acceptable
dictionaryExamples: He claimed that the restaurant bill was a legitimate business expense.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not even when he mentioned acts of violence as a legitimate way of ach[ie]ving one's goals did she react. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: allowed by law
dictionaryExamples: The army must give power back to the legitimate government.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After all, Ralph has the conch, which symbolizes legitimate power, and has been democratically elected. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: the time when you are not working
dictionaryExamples: leisure activities
Most people have a limited amount of leisure time.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: I don't have much leisure time. 
 Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: an oval, yellow fruit that has sour juice
dictionaryExamples: lemon juice
For this recipe you need the juice of two lemons.
Do you take lemon with your tea?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We drink juice and tea with lemon. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Pashto

sense.def: a cold drink made with the juice of lemons, water, and sugar
dictionaryExamples: There's both lemonade and iced tea in the fridge.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can even just relax and sunbathe while you drink a nice, cold lemonade. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to give something to someone for a short period of time, expecting it to be given back
dictionaryExamples: She doesn't like lending her books.
If you need a sweater I can lend you one/lend one to you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can meet at 6:00pm. I can ask my father to lend us the car. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: If a bank lends money, it gives money to someone who then pays the money back in small amounts over a period of time.
dictionaryExamples: Does the bank lend to small businesses?

sense.def: to be suitable for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: The novel's complex, imaginative style does not lend itself to translation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last but not least, the fact that he managed to reconquer the realm of rock music for the German tongue lends itself to be[ing] displayed, together with similar efforts by bands like Aurhefu, who achieved a similar "resurrection" for the Welsh language. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the measurement or distance of something from one end to the other
dictionaryExamples: The boat is 20 feet in length.
The length of the living room is 25 feet, the width is 12 feet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The new one has a length of 2.10 metres. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: the amount of time something takes
dictionaryExamples: the length of a film/speech/play
He doesn't seem able to concentrate for any length of time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We will need you to start the talk at 7:00 p.m. with a length of one hour. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the amount of writing in a book or document
dictionaryExamples: He's written books of various lengths on the subject.
All of your essays will be about the same length.

blocks.phrase: the length and breadth of sth

sense.def: in every part of a place
dictionaryExamples: They traveled the length and breadth of the country together.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is the reason that we can easily see the foreigners wandering [the] length and breadth [of] the museum being unaware of the origin of items they look at. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: If you talk about something at length, you talk for a long time.
dictionaryExamples: We discussed both topics at length.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since we have already arranged for your family to come to stay in my home and discussed the arrangements at length and in detail, I will no longer bother you with terms of payment and other information that, judging by your letter, seems to be quite irrelevant. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to not allow someone to become too friendly with you
dictionaryExamples: I always had the feeling she was keeping me at arm's length.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first she keeps them at arm's length, but Mr. Emerson is direct and advises Lucy to behave in a more natural way instead of doing what some old ladies say. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to become longer or to make something longer
dictionaryExamples: There are plans to lengthen the school day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, I suggest [...] that you lengthen the stay in Cambridge which was definitely too short. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: continuing for a long time
dictionaryExamples: a lengthy discussion/process

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also, soap operas are lengthy, some famous ones has even been showing for several years, which makes it possible to focus on different aspects of life and different stages in the characters' lives. International English Language Testing System; C1; Arabic

sense.def: A lenient punishment is not severe.
dictionaryExamples: He asked the judge to pass a lenient sentence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Court had been too lenient towards his detested father. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a large wild cat that has yellow fur with black spots on it and lives in Africa and southern Asia
dictionaryExamples: We saw leopards in their natural habitat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We saw different kinds of animals like a leopard, a buffalo and so on. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: not as much
dictionaryExamples: Exercise more and eat less.
We go to the movies less often than we used to.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I prefer summer [clothes] because they're less heavy than the winter ones. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: almost or approximately
dictionaryExamples: They have more or less completed the work on the house.
