The dresser weighs 50 pounds, more or less.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will [now] give you some information, so that you know more or less what you can expect. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: not as much
dictionaryExamples: We’ve got to spend less money.
I drink less coffee than I used to.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to pay less money [on] my bills. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Polish

sense.def: not as much
dictionaryExamples: I earn less than my brother.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My books cost less than the regular price. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: to become less or to make something less
dictionaryExamples: Exercise and a healthy diet lessen the chance of heart disease.
Strengthen the legs and it lessens the strain on the knees.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Should you give back the students' money and take into consideration our complaints, I am sure that you will lessen our disappointment. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a period of time when a teacher teaches people
dictionaryExamples: How can we make science lessons more interesting?
Did you ever take piano lessons?
He gives French lessons.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One lesson take[s] 45 minutes. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: an experience that teaches you how to behave better in a similar situation in the future
dictionaryExamples: There is a lesson in this tragic accident.
Losing his job was a lesson he never forgot.
We can learn important lessons  from this.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think he learned a valuable lesson. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to decide not to do something again because it has caused you problems in the past
dictionaryExamples: I'm not going out without my umbrella again - I've learned my lesson!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Actually, I am happy to hear that journalists have learned their lesson from the death of Princess Diana and try to let her children and [the] Royal family have more privacy. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to punish someone so that they will not behave badly again
dictionaryExamples: The next time she's late, go without her. That should teach her a lesson.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He didn't want to hurt Diane just teach her a lesson. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: able to cause death
dictionaryExamples: a lethal injection/weapon
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If we learn from the mistakes and there are no more wars, governments will donate money [to] social needs rather than assigning enormous sums on maintaining huge armies and inventing new types of lethal weapon[s]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a written message that you send to someone, usually in the mail
dictionaryExamples: I got a letter from Francine this morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got your letter yesterday. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Luganda

sense.def: a symbol that is used in written language and that represents a sound in that language
dictionaryExamples: the letter D
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: I bought a pair of yellow and blue jeans. . . . And also a green T-shirt with letters on it. 
 Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a plant with large green leaves, eaten raw in salads
dictionaryExamples: Do you want lettuce and tomato on your sandwich?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It contains two burgers, cheese, lettuce, tomato and [any]thing else that you want to put [i]n it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: someone's ability compared to other people
dictionaryExamples: a course for beginner/intermediate/advanced level students
Students at this level require a lot of help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The level is elementary. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: the amount or number of something
dictionaryExamples: He achieved a high level of skill as an interpreter.
Chess requires a very high level of concentration.
There is some danger of low-level  radiation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Your body requires a high level of nutrients to keep body functions working smoothly. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: the height of something
dictionaryExamples: The water level in the lake is much higher after a heavy rain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also, due to global warming, sea levels might rise and [the] risk of flooding will also rise. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: a position within a system in which people are arranged according to their importance
dictionaryExamples: These are subjects for discussion at management level.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But there is one big problem if the women can reach the upper management level: those women won't have any children. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: flat or horizontal
dictionaryExamples: The floor isn't level.
Make sure the camera is level before you take the picture.
Before I attach it to the wall, would you take a look and tell me if this shelf is level?

sense.def: when you are legally responsible for something
dictionaryExamples: They have admitted liability for the damage caused.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As soon as I had noticed it, I went to complain to the driver and he just disclaimed liability. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: someone or something that is likely to cause you a lot of trouble
dictionaryExamples: Wherever we go she upsets someone - she's a real liability.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It destroys the individual, brings shame to his family, and [he becomes] a liability instead of an asset to his society. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: legally responsible
dictionaryExamples: Corporate officials are liable for the safety of their employees.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As per our terms and conditions you are liable to pay for any damages occur[r]ed during the move and that is why we paid more money or premium to your Company than the others. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: to be likely to do something
dictionaryExamples: He's liable to make a fuss if you wake him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have taught them what is right and what is wrong, but also that a person is liable to make mistakes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who tells lies
dictionaryExamples: He's such a liar - you can't trust a word he says.
You liar - I never touched it!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The plan works: the jury thinks that the wife is a notorious liar and her husband is found innocent. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: accepting beliefs and behavior that are new or different from your own
dictionaryExamples: a liberal society/attitude
Her parents were far more liberal than mine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In a liberal society everything depends on a mixture of wise legislation and responsible individual behavior. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: Liberal political ideas emphasize the need to make new laws as society changes and the need for government to provide social services.
dictionaryExamples: a liberal policy/position
They are one of a group of liberal parties in the European Union.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He studied law in Paris and got involved in politics as a member of the liberal party during the first years of the last century. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: when something or someone is released or made free
dictionaryExamples: the liberation of France from Nazi occupation
Leaving school was such a liberation for me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, with the liberation of Greece, he was appointed as the First Governor of the new state. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the freedom to live as you wish or go where you want
dictionaryExamples: individual liberties
Our group is fighting for independence, liberty, democracy, and peace.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Personally, I think [a zoo] is a cruel way to [im]prison them after such a long period of time [when] they have been useful to Man, who is now depriving them of their liberty, preventing them from hunting and forcing them to eat what they are given. First Certificate in English; B2; Arabic

blocks.phrase: take the liberty of doing sth

sense.def: to do something that will have an effect on someone else, without asking their permission
dictionaryExamples: I took the liberty of booking theater seats for us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have taken the liberty of listing some of my ideas and suggestions and hope they will be of interest to you. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

blocks.phrase: be at liberty to do sth

sense.def: to be allowed to do something
dictionaryExamples: I'm not at liberty to discuss the matter at present.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On [the] one hand the child is at liberty to do whatever it pleases to do but on the other hand it was never taught the responsibilities implicit[l]y tied to such actions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: a room or building that contains a collection of books and other written material that you can read or borrow
dictionaryExamples: a public/school library
a library book
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's important because I want some books from the library, [and] without [a] library card [I] can't take any [out]. Key English Test; A2; Urdu

sense.def: an official document that allows you to do or have something
dictionaryExamples: a fishing/driver's license
You're going to lose your license if you keep getting speeding tickets.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: I would like to sell my b[i]c[y]cle. I have used it for two years.  I don't need it, because I've got [a] driv[er’s] license. 
 
 Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: to move your tongue across the surface of something
dictionaryExamples: He licked the chocolate off his fingers.
She licked the stamps and stuck them on the package.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As soon as I come home, she jumps on me and licks my face. [...] Princess is my ideal dog. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a cover on a container, which can be lifted up or removed
dictionaryExamples: Can you get the lid off this jar?
Be sure the lid is on the trash can.

sense.def: to be in or move your body into a horizontal position
dictionaryExamples: to lie in bed
to lie on a beach
to lie on your side/back
A cat lay in front of the fire.
He lies awake at night, worrying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think Marmaris is the best place for you because you always want to lie on a beach. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: to be on a particular surface
dictionaryExamples: A pen lay on the desk.
There were papers lying all over the floor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hurried into the airport to find my suitcase lying in one corner. Preliminary English Test; B1; Hindi

sense.def: to be in a particular place or position
dictionaryExamples: The river lies 40 miles to the south.
You shouldn’t leave that money lying around.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It lies in the south of the Czech Republic and it's [a] lovely place where you can spend your holiday. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: If responsibility, blame, a decision, a choice, etc., lies with someone, they have responsibility, must make the decision, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Responsibility for the disaster must ultimately lie with the government.
Where does the blame lie?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The greater responsibility lies with us to keep our villages and cities clean and, therefore, healthy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If an event or situation that will cause problems lies ahead, it will happen in the future.
dictionaryExamples: He's under no illusions about the difficulties that lie ahead for the industry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They help prepare our children for what lies ahead of them. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to move into a position in which your body is flat, usually in order to sleep or rest
dictionaryExamples: I'm going to lie down and take a short nap.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes I want [to] relax and lie down on the bed to watch TV. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to say or write something which is not true in order to deceive someone
dictionaryExamples: Are you lying to me?
Don't trust her - she's lying.
I suspect he lies about his age.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She lied [to] me and said she could not come with me because she had work. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: something that you say which you know is not true
dictionaryExamples: I told a lie when I said I liked her haircut.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The [e-]mail was full of lies about things that I had never done. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the time between a person's birth and their death
dictionaryExamples: Life's too short to worry about money!
I'm not sure I want to spend the rest of my life in this town.
Unfortunately, accidents are part of life.
He doesn't know what he really wants out of life.
He lost his life  in the Great War.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Aleksandra likes [to] do almost everything because she likes life! Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: everything which is alive
dictionaryExamples: animal/marine/plant life
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I chose to visit the London Aquarium because I had never gone to an aquarium [to see] sea life before. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a way of living
dictionaryExamples: You lead an exciting life.
A vacation is a pleasant change from everyday life.
Teaching has been her whole life.

sense.def: one part of someone's existence
dictionaryExamples: I never talk about my private life.
I like to keep my home life and work life separate, so I don't bring work home from the office.
my working life
We interviewed senior politicians, famous writers and others in public life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The film [is] about family life. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: the manner in which a person lives
dictionaryExamples: She told us all about her way of life in Japan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He told me about his hobbies, his way of life and especially about his love [of] learning languages. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: the existence of a person
dictionaryExamples: Many lives are lost to TB.
A simple mixture of glucose and water can save lives in many parts of the world.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally if you witness an accident you [should] inform the police quickly, which can save lives. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: energy or enthusiasm
dictionaryExamples: She's so full of life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Above all, I like children very much because the[y're] full of life [and] always make a great impression on me when I have a chat with them. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: for the whole of someone's life
dictionaryExamples: I will have to take this medicine for life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A wedding opens a new life when the two parties commit to each other for life. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

sense.def: the amount of time that a machine, system, etc., exists or can be used
dictionaryExamples: The newer batteries have a much longer life.
Careful use will prolong the life of your machine.
The legislation won't be passed during the life of the present parliament.

blocks.phrase: a matter of life and death

sense.def: a serious situation where people could die
dictionaryExamples: Getting water to these people is a matter of life and death.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I told him it was a matter of life and death. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: for all of your life
dictionaryExamples: a lifelong friend/ambition/interest
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Education is a lifelong process and you never stop learning. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the amount of time that a person lives or a thing exists
dictionaryExamples: The average human life span has increased steadily over the last century.
Some electrical products have a short life span.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now, that the life span has increased, it is becoming more and more common to see children looking after their elderly parents. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the way that you live
dictionaryExamples: He lives a healthy lifestyle.
an active lifestyle
She needs a good income to support her lifestyle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to go on a[n] advent[u]re like this, with a group of people with different backgrounds, cultures and lifestyles. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: the period of time that someone is alive
dictionaryExamples: I expect to see a lot more technological change during/in my lifetime.
I've only been working here two days, but it seems like a lifetime.
This is the opportunity of a lifetime!
A watch of this quality should last a lifetime.
You're just renting a summer house - it's not a lifetime commitment!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sure you would love it, meeting so many famous musicians, who you might meet only once in a lifetime. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: to move something from a lower to a higher position
dictionaryExamples: Could you help me lift this table, please?
Could you lift your chair a bit - I've got my bag caught under it.
She lifted the cup (up)to her lips.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then, we lift[ed] weight[s] to get stronger legs, arms, etc. I met different people [and] I made lots of friends. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a free ride somewhere in another person's car
dictionaryExamples: Can you give me a lift to the airport?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My mother will drive us and give us a lift home. Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

sense.def: a piece of equipment which produces light, such as a lamp or a light bulb
dictionaryExamples: Could you turn the light on/off, please?
She could see the city lights in the distance.
As the lights went down, the audience grew quiet.
My front bike light isn't working.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Nick I'm writing about the concert at school. [...] I can help you on Saturday morning to [set up] the light[s] and equipment. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: the brightness that comes from the sun, fire, etc. and from electrical devices, and that allows things to be seen
dictionaryExamples: bright light
Light was streaming in through the windows.
This room faces north, so it doesn't get much light.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: I have to buy a lamp for my desk because I don't have much light. 
 Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If something is done or happens in the light of facts, it is done or happens because of those facts.
dictionaryExamples:
In  light of 
                    the problems we’re having, we have no choice but to close the business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In light of all the things mentioned above, I strongly recommend Alexandra for the job. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: If information about something comes to light, it is learned or discovered.
dictionaryExamples: She knew that the fraud would eventually come to light.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, during the time they are in the forest, it comes to light that Edward is the weaker character. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If information is brought to light, it is learned or discovered.
dictionaryExamples: Her research has brought to light new information about Jefferson’s early life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The evening investigation which was carried out by [the] mysterious Inspector brought all these facts to light. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to provide new information about something that makes it easier to understand
dictionaryExamples: As an economist, he was able to shed some light on the situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A study of them might shed light on this unique process of adaptation, and may help improve it in the future. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: Light colors are pale.
dictionaryExamples: light blue/green
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am going to paint it light blue. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: not heavy
dictionaryExamples: a light summer dress
Here, take this suitcase - it's pretty light.
He's a few pounds lighter than he used to be.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: I bought a coat.  I bought it because is very light. 
 Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: lit by the natural light of the day
dictionaryExamples: It gets light very early these summer mornings.
In July, it stays light until almost 9:00 p.m.
Let's finish the work while it's still light enough to see.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the center of the town, streets are narrow and in many cases, they [ar]en't light enough. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: small in amount
dictionaryExamples: A light breeze was blowing.
Traffic was light so we got home pretty quickly.
It's just a light rain.
I don't eat much for lunch - just a light snack.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather here is very warm and sunny with [a] light breeze. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to talk or behave as if you do not think a problem is serious
dictionaryExamples: I just laughed and tried to make light of it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They project an optimistic image and make light of the troubles in life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to start to burn or to make something start to burn
dictionaryExamples: to light a fire
I can't get the barbecue to light.
I tried to light the fire, but the wood was wet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We [put up] the tents and lit the fire. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to produce light somewhere so that you can see things
dictionaryExamples: Fireworks lit up the sky.
A lantern hanging from a tree branch lit our campsite.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lightning lit up my bedroom and I saw a shadow moving outside the house. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a small object that produces a flame and is used to start something burning
dictionaryExamples: Can I borrow your lighter?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a [silver] lighter, with a little spider on, that my best friend bought me for my birthday. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: the light created by electrical equipment, candles, etc.
dictionaryExamples: outdoor lighting
The lighting in the living room is too dim.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I fixed the lighting on the ceiling and attached several spotlights to the walls. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: gently
dictionaryExamples: She patted him lightly on the shoulder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather here is wonderful, the sun is shining, the wind is blowing lightly, and the sky is also clear, clear, blue! Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: not much
dictionaryExamples: lightly cooked vegetables

sense.def: to think carefully about something before you do it, knowing that it is serious
dictionaryExamples: It's not a decision that I take lightly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you give my suggestion further consideration and not treat it lightly. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a sudden flash of light in the sky during a storm
dictionaryExamples: thunder and lightning
a flash of lightning
That tree was struck by lightning.
She changed her clothes with lightning speed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were sitting in the car when the lightning hit the roof. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: similar to or in the same way as someone or something
dictionaryExamples: She's a lot like her mother.
She looks like her father.
I have a sweater just like that.
This soda tastes like coffee!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the game, we had a barbecue and I met Theresa, a very good-looking girl who is interested in politics, just like me. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: something you say when you want someone to describe someone or something
dictionaryExamples: I haven't met him - what's he like?
So what's your new dress like?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What is she like? Preliminary English Test; B1; Lithuanian

sense.def: such as
dictionaryExamples: I prefer natural fabrics like cotton and wool.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have visit[ed] beautiful places like Chile, Patagonia, Iguazu. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: typical or characteristic of
dictionaryExamples: He forgot his keys? Well, that's just like him.
It's not like you to be so quiet - are you all right?

sense.def: a lot
dictionaryExamples: Mark’s working like crazy  to get the house painted by the end of the week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was working like crazy but I enjoyed [it]  a lot. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: very quickly
dictionaryExamples: Mark’s working like crazy  to get the house painted by the end of the week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My heart was beating like crazy and when the ski-boat started its journey along the blue waves of the sea... Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: used to remind someone that you said this earlier
dictionaryExamples: Like I said, I’m not interested in buying insurance at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wonder if it's not too late for my own little munchkins.  Like I said, they already love to SHOP! International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: similar to or approximately
dictionaryExamples: He paid something like $18,000 for his car.
The town’s Algonquian name means something like "water over a white bottom."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To their minds it is still something like an obligation and this may be attributed to the pressure their parents and teachers used to put on them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to enjoy something or feel that someone or something is pleasant
dictionaryExamples: I like your new haircut.
Do you like fish?
I like it when a book is so good that you can't put it down.
I don't like upsetting people.
He's very well-liked  at work.
He likes to spend his evenings in front of the television.
I like taking my time in the morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like reading and writing. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used to say that you want something
dictionaryExamples: I'd like the tomato soup, please.
I'd like to go to Moscow.
We would like to thank all of you for making our wedding such a special occasion!
I'd like two tickets for tonight's performance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to study other languages, too. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used to ask someone if they want something
dictionaryExamples: Would you like a cup of coffee?
Would you like to eat now?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Would you like to come? Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish

sense.def: used when you offer someone something
dictionaryExamples: If you like, I could drive you there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you like, we can go to a night club. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: as if
dictionaryExamples: It looks like rain.
It looks like I'll be home late tonight.
It sounds to me like you ought to change jobs.
You look like you've you need some sleep.
Sometimes it seems like I'll never be finished!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It seems like all my new friends like me a lot, and I am very happy to stay in this school. Preliminary English Test; B1; Norwegian

sense.def: things that you do and do not like
dictionaryExamples: She knows her children’s likes and dislikes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The teacher asked about our families, friends, [and] likes and dislikes and [then] the lesson finished. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the chance that something will happen
dictionaryExamples: There’s little likelihood of a compromise.
There's not much likelihood of that happening.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is little likelihood of having a good place to live in without the scientists' support. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: almost certainly
dictionaryExamples: The facilities are wasted on people who in all likelihood will not use them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In all likelihood, you will have to work during the weekends, even in summer, so I firmly believe that loving your job is very important. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: describes something that will probably happen or is expected
dictionaryExamples: If I don’t write it down, I’m likely to forget.
I suppose that could happen, but it's not likely.
I'm more likely to be home on Saturday than on Sunday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They start thinking that the suitcase is likely to contain a bomb. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: probably
dictionaryExamples: I’ll most likely get there at about ten o’clock.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You will most likely not get there before 2:30. Welcome! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: in the same way
dictionaryExamples: Water these plants twice a week and likewise the ones in the bedroom.
Watch what she does and then do likewise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And likewise, common sense tells us it doesn't matter that oranges from Spain contain 0.01% more vitamin C than those from Florida, as long as we eat them every once in a while. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: the largest amount of something that is possible or allowed
dictionaryExamples: Is there a limit on the number of tickets you can get?
Two cups of coffee - that's my limit.
I think we ought to put a limit on the amount of time we can spend on the project.
There's a limit to my patience.
We set a time limit of thirty minutes for the test.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I always watch this program, it's really interesting for anyone who enjoy[s] cooking. [...] Usually two chef[s] come in and prepare the food, and they hav[e] a time limit. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Nepali

sense.def: to drive faster than you are allowed to according to the law
dictionaryExamples: She was exceeding the speed limit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are three ground rules you have to follow: stop at stop signs, don't exceed the speed limit and don't be in the way of other cars. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to control something so that it is less than a particular amount or number
dictionaryExamples: I've been asked to limit my talk to ten minutes.
Having so little money to spend on an apartment does limit your choices.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In general, kids and teenagers are, at home, allowed to do almost anything they want, wh[ich] sometimes put[s] parents in a very difficult position when trying to [e]stablish rules in order to limit the freedom of the young. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: control or rules that limit the size or extent of something
dictionaryExamples: You can't write everything you want because of space limitations.
They favor anything that involves limitation of government control.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The only thing that is crucial now is that ministries of culture and tourism should set strict limitations about building and constructing in order not to [destroy] the stunning views of our beautiful country. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: things that someone or something is not good at doing
dictionaryExamples: Both films show her limitations as an actress.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to be a super-woman but I will have to live with my limitations. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: small in amount or number
dictionaryExamples: a limited choice
limited resources
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like warm colors, orange and yellow, but my choices are limited for outdoor clothes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: kept within a particular size, range, time, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The class is limited to fifty students.
The free backpack is available for a limited time only.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Above all, [w]ould it possible to enjoy the offer in September or is it limited to July? First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a long, thin mark
dictionaryExamples: a straight line
Sign your name on the dotted line.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have to bring with us only [a] pencil.  Because [the] first day we will draw lines. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: a group of people standing one behind the other who are waiting for something
dictionaryExamples: Are you in line?
There was a long line at the movie theater.
Just get in/on line and wait your turn like everyone else.
I had to wait/stand in line for three hours to get tickets.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The next day, he was in the airport waiting in line to check in his luggage. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a row of words on a page
dictionaryExamples: The same line is repeated throughout the poem.
Can you read the next line, please, Sonia?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In no more than ten lines, my mother explained that she was moving to Brazilia, the capital of our country, and that she would take me and my brother with her. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a train route or railroad track
dictionaryExamples: rail/commuter lines
Wet leaves on the track delayed trains on both lines this morning.
the Hudson Line/the Raritan Valley Line
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You go up along the Yourou river [on] the Kominato line and you can find some beautiful place[s]. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: the connection between telephones
dictionaryExamples: That line is busy – may I take a message?
I've got Chris Foster on the line for you.
Please hold the line. I'll see if she's available.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Bedrooms were quite spacious with a lot of light as well as a TV set and a direct phone line. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a type of product that a company sells
dictionaryExamples: Our new sportswear line will be in stores shortly.
They're advertising a new line of garden furniture.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If, on [the] one hand, the changing market is forcing us to [remove]  some product lines, on the other [it] is giving us new opportunities, as is the case for handhelds. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: a very small difference between two things that seem very different
dictionaryExamples: There's a fine line between courage and foolishness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It took me 6 months to reali[z]e that there is a fine line between telling off and psychological abuse. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

sense.def: a row of people or things
dictionaryExamples: a line of trees
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Its facade was cut by a line of French windows and there was a large number of people in front of the front door. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the border of an area within a country
dictionaryExamples: the city/state/county line

sense.def: a long mark on an area where a sport is played that shows an edge or measurement
dictionaryExamples: the foul line
the 50-yard line

sense.def: a way of dealing with or thinking about something or someone
dictionaryExamples: I couldn’t follow his line of reasoning.
Some members of Congress disagree with their party's line on tax cuts.
The police are confident that this new line of investigation will lead them to the murderer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My personal take on this line of thought is that this is a practical and beneficial albeit shallow way to view reading books, re[duc]ing reading to a simple pastime. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a row of positions used to defend against enemy attack, especially the ones closest to enemy positions
dictionaryExamples: They were taken prisoner while on a reconnaissance mission behind enemy lines.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was never afraid of going to the front line [in] battle. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If someone's job, reputation, life, etc., is on the line, they may lose it.
dictionaryExamples: If we don't win the contract, all our jobs are on the line.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The person who hopes to achieve success shouldn't be afraid of taking risks and sometimes putting his or her career on the line for the sake of gaining much bigger benefits. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the most important fact of final result in an activity, discussion, or situation
dictionaryExamples: The bottom line is that they lost the game.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The bottom line is that the adults of today have to stop for a second and think about what they are doing. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: based on and similar to something
dictionaryExamples: He gave a talk along the lines of the one he gave in Oxford.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Imagine one is encouraged by friends and institutions for their 'different' artistic or other activities, even if their works are not along the lines of 'acceptable' norms and tradition. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: to be similar to and suitable for something
dictionaryExamples: They were offered a pay increase in line with inflation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The other two courses, at 5%, are still in line with the national average. International English Language Testing System; C2; Afrikaans

sense.def: in the future
dictionaryExamples: Lots of things will have changed a few years down the road.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For that very reason it seemed natural for Laura and John to take her in, and further down the line they would adopt her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: If someone says they know where to draw the line, they are talking about knowing at what point an activity or situation becomes unacceptable because it is wrong or too extreme
dictionaryExamples: I’ll do what I can to help a friend, but I draw the line when someone asks me to lie for them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For these parents, drawing the line at certain behaviors became a s[y]nonym for lack of democracy, and a source of struggle at home. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If someone's actions or words are out of line, they are beyond what is considered acceptable in that situation.
dictionaryExamples: You can disagree with her, but calling her dishonest was way out of line.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Today I see that my mother was right in this aspect since I acted extremely out of line sometimes and a soft hand certainly wouldn't help me in the future. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If you read between the lines, you understand what something really means when it hasn't been directly said or written.
dictionaryExamples: Reading between the lines, it was obvious that something was wrong.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All songs send positive thoughts and messages to listeners, although sometimes you really have to read between the lines to understand this profound message. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to form a row along the side of something
dictionaryExamples: Trees and cafes lined the street.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Under the arch formed by the top branches of the trees which lined both sides of the street, she was so much absorbed in her thought that she did not hear the sound of approaching steps. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to arrange people or things in a row or to stand in a row
dictionaryExamples: A fight broke out behind me as we lined up to receive our food rations.
The soldiers lined us up against a wall and I thought they were going to shoot us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A lot of customers had lined up after me. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to plan for something to happen
dictionaryExamples: What future projects have you lined up?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nonetheless, we are also eager to help out in other projects that you have lined up. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to stay somewhere for a long time
dictionaryExamples: The smell from the fire still lingered hours later.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many recollections of that evening have perished, like how I worked up the nerve to ask her, but one thing that lingers in my mind is that song we danced to. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: relating to language or the study of language
dictionaryExamples: I'm particularly interested in the linguistic development of young children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, the claim that only one hour per day was required in order to obtain linguistic fluency is an unrealistic assumption. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a connection between documents or areas on the Internet
dictionaryExamples: Click on this link to visit our online bookstore.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An au-pair friend of mine ha[s] given me a link to an au-pair homepage. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a connection between two people, things, or ideas
dictionaryExamples: There's a link between diet and heart disease.
A high-speed rail link brings you to the airport.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a direct bus link between the two locations: this is bus line number six. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to make a connection between two or more people, things, or ideas
dictionaryExamples: The use of CFCs has been linked to the hole in the ozone layer.
This is the only bridge linking the island with the mainland.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The technological revolution taking place today can be directly linked to the amazing evolution [of] communication. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a large, wild animal of the cat family, with light brown fur
dictionaryExamples: The lions came down to the water hole at sunset.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My favorite present is a lion. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: one of the two soft edges of the mouth
dictionaryExamples: He licked his lips.
My lips are dry from the cold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We went to a restaurant and when I had to leave, he kissed me on my lips. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: a substance, such as water, that is not solid or a gas and that can be poured easily
dictionaryExamples: liquid fuel/nitrogen
Mercury is a liquid at room temperature.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Inside there were three samples of a nasty purple liquid. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a series of names, numbers, or items that are written one below the other
dictionaryExamples: a shopping list
Is your name on the list?
I've made a list of places I'd like to visit while we're in Paris.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [Our] class teacher will give us a list of thing[s] we must buy. Key English Test; A2; Tupi/Gurani

sense.def: to make a list, or to include something in a list
dictionaryExamples: I've listed some useful reading material on the handout.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I listed some reasons why we should apply for this job. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to give attention to someone or something in order to hear them
dictionaryExamples: What kind of music do you listen to?
She does all the talking - I just sit and listen.
You haven't listened to a word I've said!
We listened in silence as their names were read out.
Listen, if you need money, I'm happy to lend you some.
Listen to this! You can win a holiday for two in the south of France just by answering three simple questions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She likes to listen [to] oriental music and Turkish music. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: to pay attention to what someone tells you and accept what they say
dictionaryExamples: I told you she wouldn't like it but you wouldn't listen to me!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I did complain many time[s] but he wouldn't listen to me. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; French

sense.def: to secretly listen to someone else's conversation
dictionaryExamples: Do you think he's been listening in on our conversations?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As John kept coming back late from work and giving the same kind of excuse, Maria decided to bug his phone at work as well as his workplace and then began to listen in on him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: someone who listens
dictionaryExamples: The new radio station already has twelve million listeners.
She's a good listener.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is a good listener, as well as quite talkative. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a unit for measuring the volume of a liquid, equal to 1.057 quarts
dictionaryExamples: a liter of water/soda
Pick up a two-liter bottle of spring water while you're at the store.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also try to drink at least 2 liter[s] of water a day. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: the ability to read and write
dictionaryExamples: Adult literacy is low in this area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: School on the one hand has been a place to learn the important basi[c]s, like literacy and numeracy. International English Language Testing System; C1; Luxemburgish

sense.def: The literal meaning of a word or phrase is its real or original meaning.
dictionaryExamples: the literal meaning/sense
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, some people treasure certain possessions since they are valuable in its literal meaning, like diamonds or gold. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: having the real or original meaning of a word or phrase
dictionaryExamples: There were literally hundreds of pages to read in the contract.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes they literally g[o] mad; they bite their mates or even kill their own children. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: connected with literature
dictionaryExamples: a literary critic
literary prizes
a literary style
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since I am aware of your interest in literature, I have chosen a literary figure. First Certificate in English; B2; Farsi

sense.def: able to read and write
dictionaryExamples: He was barely literate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum up, in no way is education a waste of time. What we do need is [to] improve it and make people believe that being educated and literate is a great asset. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: books, poems, etc. that are considered to be art
dictionaryExamples: American/French/world literature
contemporary literature
great works of literature
The course in English literature covers Shakespeare’s plays.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He has studied English literature at Cambridge University. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: pieces of paper and other waste that are left in public places
dictionaryExamples: The streets were full of litter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There [is] a lot of litter on the streets. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: small in size or amount
dictionaryExamples: It came in a little box.
a little dog/nose/room
He gave a little smile.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I [am] swimming, I can see the little fish. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: young
dictionaryExamples: When you were little your hair was really curly.
She's my little  sister.
Her little boy  isn't well.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She has a little boy. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: not important
dictionaryExamples: I had a little problem with my car, but it’s fixed now.
She gets really upset by every little thing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is only one little problem. Unfortunately, [the] rooms are single. Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian

sense.def: short in time or distance
dictionaryExamples: It’ll take me a little while longer to get ready.
Let's have a little break.
It's only a little way to the school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was on a phone for a little while and the lights went out... who knows why!! First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: used to show affection or dislike for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Oh, what a nice little house!
It's not a bad little restaurant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Oh no Mr. Dracula...don't hurt me! Please don't hurt me!" I said desperately. "With such a pretty little neck? Oh no! I have to give you just a tiny little bite..."First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: not much or enough
dictionaryExamples: There seems little hope of a ceasefire.
They have very little money.
There's so little choice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In his opinion, [being a] teacher is a very bad way to earn money because you have a lot of work to do and earn very little money. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a small amount of something
dictionaryExamples: It just needs a little effort.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi Sam, I need a little help from you. I need [to borrow] your bicycle, because someone stole mine. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a small amount
dictionaryExamples: I could only hear a little of what they were saying.
He does as little as possible at work.
There's not much flour left but you're welcome to the/what little there is.
She slept very little that night.
We did very little on Sunday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He told them how animals were treated by human beings -  they had to work a lot and were fed very little. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a small amount
dictionaryExamples: "Do we have any sugar left?" "A little."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One day it rained, but only a little. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a small amount at  a time
dictionaryExamples: Little by little, the boy learned to trust us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, as the time went by, I couldn't but feel my dream disappearing little by little. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: slightly
dictionaryExamples: I was a little bit worried by what she said.
Let's wait just a little bit longer before I call them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a little bit expensive but it is so awesome! Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: slightly
dictionaryExamples: You’re walking a little too fast for me.
She was a little frightened.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm a little surprised by my "popularity". First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: not much or not enough
dictionaryExamples: a little-known fact
Little did he know what was in store for him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Little did I know that I would be even more confused afterward. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: not much more or better
dictionaryExamples: Their house was little more than a hovel.
Their electricity was off for a week and we did little better - five days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was little better than a slum, completely unfurnished, except f[or] a desk with a diary on it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: full of energy and interest
dictionaryExamples: It's hard work teaching a class of lively children.
a lively city
They take a lively interest in their grandchildren.
There was some lively discussion at the meeting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Paris is very lively all day long and at night. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a large organ in your body that cleans your blood
dictionaryExamples: He has something wrong with his liver.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Peter knew that her injuries would not be a problem, except her liver.  That is why the surgeon asked him if he could give his sister a part of his liver. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: alive now
dictionaryExamples: living things/creatures/organisms
He is probably the best known living architect.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Environmental protection activists point out that living creatures shouldn't be deprived of their natural background and most endangered species could be saved from extinction by creating more national parks. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the money that you earn from your job
dictionaryExamples: What do you do for a living?
You can earn/make a good living  in sales if you have the right attitude.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should try to earn a living [from] painting. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the room in a house where people sit to relax and, for example, watch television
dictionaryExamples: We had dinner in the living room and watched a movie on TV.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My favorite room is the living room because it's the biggest in my house. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: bread that has been baked in one large piece so that it can be cut into smaller pieces
dictionaryExamples: a loaf of bread
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was often sent by my mother to the next shop to buy a loaf of bread, some milk and sometimes fruit and vegetables. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: money that someone has borrowed
dictionaryExamples: She's going to take out a loan to start her own business.
We'd have to get a loan to be able to buy a car.
My brother repaid his student loan within five years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From [the program] they learn a lot about funding or [getting a] loan from [a] bank. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Polish

sense.def: If something is on loan, someone is borrowing it.
dictionaryExamples: Both paintings are on loan from the city museum.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, you can always take out on loan any video you like from our center. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: to hate someone or something
dictionaryExamples: I absolutely loathe swimming.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even those obscure and never-pay-attention subjects that we totally loathe might give us food for thought regardless of what we will end up studying. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a feeling of hating someone or something
dictionaryExamples: All I feel for him is loathing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Both characters are torn between their feelings of awe and loathing for India, although Olivia's relationship with this country is one of submission and devotion. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: an area inside the main entrance of a building
dictionaryExamples: the hotel/building lobby
I'll meet you in the lobby at 5:30.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He unpacked his things, took a shower and went to the lobby [to] wait for Hanna. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to try to persuade the government or an official group to do something
dictionaryExamples: Small businesses have lobbied hard for/against changes in the tax laws.
Local residents lobbied to have the factory shut down.
Council members have been lobbying colleagues on how to vote.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They have become so powerful through their vast sales and profits that they can effectively lobby for their points of view. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: relating to an area near you
dictionaryExamples: a local accent
local issues
a local hospital/television station
Most of the local population depend on fishing for their income.
Our children all go to the local school.
Many local stores will be close if the new mall is built.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You could go walking in the countryside, try water sports, enjoy the local food (especially the "galettes") and visit the city of Rennes. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: someone who lives in the area you are talking about
dictionaryExamples: The locals are very upset about the new law.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, it is inadvisable to confront the locals with prejudices or exaggerated expec[ta]tions they cannot live up to. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a place or position
dictionaryExamples: The hotel is in a lovely location overlooking the lake.
A map showing the location of the property will be sent to you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The village is in a peaceful location, within minutes of a safe lake, and an hour from a pretty town. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: If a film or television program is made on location, it is made at a place suitable to the story.
dictionaryExamples: The movie was shot on location in Kenya.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can't help mentioning the nice shots on location. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: the thing that is used to close a door, window, etc., and that needs a key to open it
dictionaryExamples: I heard someone turn a key in the lock.
safety locks
Thieves got in by smashing the lock off the door.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the hotel, in my room I tr[i]ed to open my suitcase but the lock d[id]n't move. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to fasten something with a key, or to be fastened with a key
dictionaryExamples: Don't forget to lock the door when you go out.
If you shut the door, it will lock automatically.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yesterday at about 11:10 p.m. I went to lock my garage. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Gujarati

sense.def: to put something or someone in a place or container that is fastened with a key
dictionaryExamples: The jewelry is locked away in a safe.
He locked the documents in his filing cabinet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With large sums of money locked away in their banks, they decided to destroy the notes in they made during the discovery, to prevent any th[ieve]s from stealing the secret. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

blocks.phrasalVerb: lock in sb or lock sb in

sense.def: to prevent someone from leaving or prevent others from entering a room or building by locking a door
dictionaryExamples: She locked herself in her bedroom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My mother was about to die from her agony while my father was trying to find a way to lock me in. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

blocks.phrasalVerb: lock out sb or lock sb out

sense.def: to prevent someone from entering a room or building by locking a door
dictionaryExamples: I can't believe I've locked myself out again!
I forgot that my dad didn't have keys, and I locked him out of the house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the very early morning, my husband and I heard a lot of noise at the front door and I went to see if Kate was locked out. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: the space under the roof of a house, often used for storing things
dictionaryExamples: We keep things like suitcases and holiday decorations in the loft.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has lots of room - two bedrooms, a spacious living room, a kitchen that's well lit and even a loft for storage. International English Language Testing System; C2; English

sense.def: a large, open apartment, often in a former industrial building
dictionaryExamples: They've bought a loft downtown that has huge windows.

sense.def: a small room under a high ceiling that has only three walls and overlooks a larger room below
dictionaryExamples: We use the loft as a library and guest room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What is extra (and makes it unique in this street) is the downstairs shower room, separate utility room and very large loft room. International English Language Testing System; C2; English

sense.def: a thick piece of tree trunk or branch, especially one cut for burning on a fire
dictionaryExamples: Let's put another log on the fire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People used to cook with fire logs [but] they don't do it any more. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to start using a computer or to connect a computer to a system of computers by typing a password and sometimes your name
dictionaryExamples: I tried to log on as usual but nothing happened.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well you need a computer and you have to log on [to] the Internet. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to stop using a computer or program or to stop a computer being connected to a computer system
dictionaryExamples: We were all asked to log off while some changes were made to the system.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know that most students just log off the computers, but they [are] still switch[ed] on and [use] energy. Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Polish

sense.def: the use of reason, or the science of using reason
dictionaryExamples: I fail to see the logic of his argument.
We'll be able to work this out if we use some logic.
There's no logic in the decision to reduce staff when orders are the highest for years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It lacked any logic or interest for me. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: using reason
dictionaryExamples: a logical choice/conclusion
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When someone is logical and smart and loves life, he is not in danger when he drives a car. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: in a way that is logical
dictionaryExamples: Her ideas were clear and logically presented.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her intuition failed her, [and] neither could she find the answer logically. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a design or symbol used by a company to advertise its products
dictionaryExamples: a corporate logo
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: I have also b[o]u[ght] some new tee-shirt[s]: one blue, one green with [a] white logo and one red. 
 Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the state of being lonely
dictionaryExamples: I wasn't prepared for the loneliness of living in a small village.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Frankenstein is a book that explores the feelings of loneliness and solitude, and the consequences that this has on human relationships. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: unhappy because you are not with other people
dictionaryExamples: She gets lonely now that all the kids have left home.
the lonely life of a farmer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If they had not been there, I would have been very lonely. Preliminary English Test; B1; Vietnamese

sense.def: A lonely place is a long way from where people live.
dictionaryExamples: a lonely stretch of Arizona highway
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In this lonely place strange things happened. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: continuing for a large amount of time
dictionaryExamples: a long movie/meeting
I've been waiting a long time.
It's a long time since I lived there.

 First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese
