sense.def: to like someone very much and have romantic feelings for them
dictionaryExamples: Last night he told me he loved me.
I've only ever loved one woman.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Stan is from Poland.  He is my husband. I love him. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Pashto

sense.def: used to say that you would very much like something
dictionaryExamples: I'd love some chocolate right now!
I'd love to be an actor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd love some chop[s] and beer. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: used to say that you would very much like to do something that someone has suggested
dictionaryExamples: "Would you like to come to the concert with us?" "I'd love to."
We'd love to go to the beach - thanks for inviting us.
We’d love to own our own home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yes, I'd love to come with you. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

blocks.phrase: love/(with) love/all my love/lots of love

sense.def: something you write at the end of a letter, e-mail, etc. to a friend or someone in your family
dictionaryExamples: Love, Mom
All my love, Louise
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lots of love, Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: when you like a friend or person in your family very much
dictionaryExamples: Nothing is as strong as the love you have for your kids.
"I'm seeing Laura next week." "Oh, please give her my love."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Give my love to your family. All the best, Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when you like someone very much and have romantic feelings for them
dictionaryExamples: He's madly in love with her.
She fell in love with her friend's brother.
"I've been seeing him over a year now." "Is it love?"
How's your love life  these days?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I fell in love with him. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a person that you love and feel attracted to
dictionaryExamples: He was the love of my life.
She was my first love.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was from the love of my life. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: something that interests you a lot
dictionaryExamples: I don't share my brother's love of sports.
Music is one of her greatest loves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Both of them symbolize courage, love of justice, fight for freedom, which makes them look like heroes. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: an activity that is hard work but which you do because you enjoy it
dictionaryExamples: He prefers to paint the house himself - it's a labor of love.

sense.def: pleasant or enjoyable
dictionaryExamples: We had a lovely time in Greece.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had a lovely time there. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: attractive and beautiful
dictionaryExamples: You look lovely in that dress.
Thank you for the lovely present.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The best time of the year would be spring because the weather will be warmer and there will be a lot of lovely flowers and the view on the mountains will be great. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: If two people are lovers, they have a romantic or physical relationship.
dictionaryExamples: They were friends before they became lovers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was reading "Romeo and Juliet" by W. Shakespeare when I suddenly decided to leave and visit Verona, the lovers' city. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: someone who is very interested in books, cats, dogs, etc.
dictionaryExamples: an  opera lover
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Brazil is a very big country and perfect for nature lovers. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: small in amount, size or level
dictionaryExamples: low temperatures
The big supermarket has the lowest prices.
These people are living on relatively low incomes.
a low-fat diet
Vegetables are generally low in  calories.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were beautiful clothes for low prices. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: not high
dictionaryExamples: a low fence
low ceilings
Until I’m a better skier, I’ll stay on the lower slopes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I stay [at] home, I wear jeans, t-shirts, low shoes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: of bad quality, especially when referring to something that is not as good as it should be
dictionaryExamples: low standards/quality
I have rather a low opinion of him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, it is necessary to add that few people could afford much food because of poverty and the low quality of life which they had. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: deep or quiet
dictionaryExamples: a low voice
a low note
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Right after I had said that, I noticed that someone was pointing at me with a gun, [and] a low voice said: "If I were you I wouldn't move, follow me." First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: not important or powerful
dictionaryExamples: low rank/status
New furniture is a very low priority at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Luminaries claim that the team spirit and the sense of competition have vanished, and it has been proven that exercise has a low priority compared to other recreational activities. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: unhappy and without energy
dictionaryExamples: She’s feeling pretty low because she failed her driver’s test.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She never feels low and I am in high spirits being with her because she has got a sense of humor. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to try not to be noticed
dictionaryExamples: She has kept a low profile since the divorce.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, I believe that the best way to handle these issues is to try to keep a low profile at all times and to remain indifferent to gossip. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: at or to a small amount or level
dictionaryExamples: Temperatures can fall as low as -20 degrees.
Can you turn the heat  down a bit lower?
That plane is flying awfully low.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The lights are down low. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to move something into a low position
dictionaryExamples: I lowered the blinds to block out the afternoon sun.
She lowered herself carefully into the chair.
He lowered his eyes  in embarrassment when he saw me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But when she asked who wanted to be a cleaner, nobody raised his hand and I felt so [a]shame[d] that I lowered my head. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to reduce the amount or level of something
dictionaryExamples: Interest rates have been lowered again.
Boil for 5 minutes, then lower the heat and simmer for half an hour.
Please lower your voice.
We will never lower our standards.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This should be done by lowering taxes and preparing other incentives for potential investors. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: always liking and supporting someone or something, sometimes when other people do not
dictionaryExamples: Jack has been a loyal employee in this company for almost 50 years.
People close to him are fiercely loyal.
She's very loyal to her friends.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the most beautiful things [i]n the world is true and loyal friendship. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the quality of being loyal
dictionaryExamples: His loyalty was never in question.
Her loyalty to the cause is impressive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What I can say is that [pets] [ar]e ideal when they obey and show loyalty to you. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: good and bad things caused by chance and not by your own actions
dictionaryExamples: It was just by luck that she got the job.
a good luck charm
She had bad luck in the last race, finishing fourth.
So your interview's tomorrow? Good luck!
The best of luck with your exams!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Good luck to you. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: success
dictionaryExamples: I’ve got a job interview today, so wish me luck.
Did you have any luck  finding a flight?
He tried to get into Harvard but, no luck.
When I met her, I couldn't believe my luck.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you might suppose, I couldn't believe my luck when I found out that I'd won first prize in the competition. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be lucky or to be able to have or do what you want
dictionaryExamples: "Do you have any tuna sandwiches?" "You're in luck - there's one left."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was in luck, because my friend, who lived in the same area, had his private car and gave me a lift every day. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: something good that happens to you by chance
dictionaryExamples: He had exactly the part that I needed so that was a stroke of luck.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After a one-hour interview she was asked whether she could start work the very next day. A real stroke of luck. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: in a lucky way
dictionaryExamples: Luckily, I had some money with me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Luckily, the weather was nice. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: having good things happen to you by chance
dictionaryExamples: "I'm going on vacation." "Lucky you!"
For ten games, the Orioles have gotten every conceivable lucky break.
They're lucky to have such a nice office to work in.
He's lucky that he wasn't fired.
Today is my lucky day!
We'll be lucky if we get there by midnight at this rate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe we will be lucky and have good weather. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: If an object is lucky, some people believe that it gives you luck.
dictionaryExamples: I chose six - it's my lucky number.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I lost my lucky pencil. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If something is lucrative, it results in a lot of money.
dictionaryExamples: a lucrative contract/job/offer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is no secret that many youngsters want a lucrative job, which would allow them [to] mak[e] money hand over fist. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: suitcases and other bags that you carry with you when you are traveling
dictionaryExamples: Never leave your luggage unattended.
carry-on luggage
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hotel is near the airport, so it was easy for me to come here with my luggage. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: wood cut into sizes to be used for building
dictionaryExamples: We can buy most of the lumber precut to the lengths we will need.
a lumber mill/yard/company
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Soon afterward, he established his own lumber company, and started to import wood items from the United States. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a piece of a solid substance with no particular shape
dictionaryExamples: a lump of coal
You don't want lumps in the sauce.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He bent down to pick it up and saw it was a lump of concrete. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

blocks.phrase: bring a lump to your throat

sense.def: to make you feel such strong emotion that you want to cry
dictionaryExamples: It was a very moving speech, and it brought a lump to my throat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This devastating image brought a lump to John's throat. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a meal that is eaten in the middle of the day
dictionaryExamples: What's for lunch?
I'm sorry, Joanna isn't here at the moment, she's (gone) out to/at lunch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We met in Bristol, and we had beer and [a] light lunch. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: the time when lunch is eaten
dictionaryExamples: It'll be lunchtime soon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please telephon[e] me at home at lunchtime. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: one of the two organs inside your chest that are used for breathing
dictionaryExamples: lung cancer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People suffering from lung diseases go there to be cured. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to persuade someone to go somewhere or do something by offering them something exciting
dictionaryExamples: It seems that he was lured into a trap.
The university hopes to lure a new coach with an attractive salary package.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of the children are lured to the big cities, in expectation of work. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: the power to attract people
dictionaryExamples: the lure of fame/power/money
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some have offered the lure of losing weight within a very few days, by the means of miraculously easy techniques. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: very comfortable and expensive
dictionaryExamples: They have a very luxurious house.
luxurious fabrics
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as the hotel is concerned, I feel that it wasn't a luxurious one. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: great comfort or pleasure from expensive or beautiful things
dictionaryExamples: a luxury cruise
a luxury hotel
to live in luxury
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm staying in a luxury hotel overlooking [the] sea. Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: something which gives you a lot of pleasure but which you cannot often do or have
dictionaryExamples: A day off work is such a luxury.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that to have this museum is a luxury for our city and we must visit [it]. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: something expensive which is pleasant to have but is not necessary
dictionaryExamples: luxuries, such as champagne and chocolate
I like to buy myself little luxuries from time to time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the time, [the] majority [of] consumers had no money to spend on luxuries.

sense.def: the words of a song
dictionaryExamples: I've downloaded the lyrics of that song you like.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the greatest [of] these musicians is Caetano Veloso, whose lyrics and melodies [touch] the hearts and souls of music lovers in Brazil and all around the world. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese
